title: Commons Speaker passed Mandelson flight risk information to police ahead of arrest
partialText: Sir Lindsay Hoyle tells MPs he was acting "in good faith as is my duty and responsibility" as he felt information was "relevant".

title: Man who murdered nine-year-old girl as she played with hula hoop in street jailed
partialText: Lilia Valutyte, 9, was playing outside a shop in Boston when she was stabbed by Deividas Skebas.

title: UK government denies Chagos Islands deal is paused, after minister said it was
partialText: It come after a minister said the UK is discussing "concerns" with the US, after President Trump criticised the deal.

title: 'Jekyll and Hyde' killer guilty of shooting ex-colleague on remote country path
partialText: Former gamekeeper David Campbell murdered Brian Low in Aberfeldy two years ago then tried to cover his tracks.

title: Tourette's campaigner says BBC 'should have worked harder' to stop his slur being aired
partialText: John Davidson, who tics due to his condition, shouted a racial slur while two black actors were on stage.

title: Fact-checking Trump's longest ever State of the Union
partialText: President Donald Trump said the US "is winning again" - making a series of claims about his record in a speech which lasted almost two hours.

title: Gucci criticised for 'AI slop' images ahead of major fashion show
partialText: Users of social media - where the marketing campaign has been launched - say it is out of keeping with Gucci's reputation for luxury.

title: UK records warmest day of the year as temperatures climb above 18C
partialText: After a relentlessly wet start to the year the UK has recorded its warmest day of the year as many places bask in the late winter sunshine.

title: Starmer promises to look at making student loans 'fairer'
partialText: Conservative leader Kemi Badenoch said the system had become a "debt trap" for graduates.

title: Household energy bills to fall in April after charges shake-up
partialText: Changes announced in the Budget mean all energy bills will see some kind of reduction, but it will vary.

title: Why scientists fear Emperor penguins' annual moult may be killing them
partialText: Each year the birds must stay on floating ice long enough to replace their weather-beaten feathers.

title: Trump keeps world waiting on his plans for Iran after State of the Union
partialText: The next round of talks between the US and Iran in Geneva on Thursday could be decisive in the president's decision-making.

title: 'I'm proud of my heritage' - meet Britain's youngest ever F1 driver
partialText: Arvid Lindblad tells BBC Sport about being shaped by his Indian and Swedish heritage and how he was fixated on reaching F1 from aged five.

title: New travel rules for UK visitors kick in today - find out how this affects you
partialText: From 25 February, a new system will come into force which will affect many people, including British dual nationals.

title: Snoop Dogg's surreal Swansea visit heralds late drama
partialText: The difference between Swansea v Preston and other second-tier matches was that one of the Welsh club's co-owners happens to be a hip-hop legend.

title: Disabled woman, 33, put in nursing home against her will feels 'betrayed'
partialText: Lucinda Ritchie, who has full mental capacity, was transferred from a hospital bed despite her refusal.

title: Will walk-in GP clinics deliver one million extra appointments in Scotland?
partialText: The first of 16 new walk-in clinics across Scotland is now open but it is not clear when a target of them delivering one million appointments will be hit.

title: Phil Collins, Pink and Shakira nominated for Rock & Roll Hall of Fame
partialText: Jeff Buckley, Lauryn Hill, Pink, Shakira and Mariah Carey are also among the 17 nominees this year.

title: Bill Gates 'took responsibility' over Epstein ties in staff meeting, foundation says
partialText: A newspaper reports Gates apologised to staff over his links to Epstein and said: "I did nothing illicit. I saw nothing illicit."

title: Man arrested after 'axe carried into mosque'
partialText: Manchester Central Mosque said the "swift actions of its volunteers" had "contained the situation".

title: Harry and Meghan visit refugee camp as part of Middle East trip
partialText: The Duke and Duchess of Sussex's trip to Jordan is their first international tour as a couple since August 2024.

title: Life sentence for man who shook girlfriend's five-month-old baby to death
partialText: Thomas Morgan's "rage-filled attack" left the five-month-old boy with catastrophic injuries.

title: Not even potholes will hold up self-driving cars, UK firm predicts
partialText: Wayve says it's confident all cars will one day be autonomous, as it announced more than a £1bn in additional investment.

title: 'Exceptionally rare' Roman lead blocks found on farmland
partialText: The objects, which were used to produce tools and weapons, were found on grazing land in west Wales.

title: BBC News app
partialText: Top stories, breaking news, live reporting, and follow news topics that match your interests

title: Trump's big, long, State of the Union speech
partialText: Can the president’s record breaking speech change voters’ minds ahead of the midterms?

title: A Woman's Hour and SEND in the Spotlight special
partialText: We hear from a range of voices on the impact of the government's SEND reforms in England.

title: Man Utd post profit but debt rises to £1.3bn
partialText: The amount Manchester United owe increases to almost £1.3bn in outstanding transfer fees, rolling credit facility and legacy debt.

title: Uefa rejects Benfica appeal over Prestianni ban
partialText: Gianluca Prestianni will miss the second leg of Benfica's Champions League tie against Real Madrid after Uefa reject the club's appeal against his suspension.

title: What should England do about Jos Buttler?
partialText: What are the options facing England amid Jos Buttler's struggles at the T20 World Cup. Could they really drop their former captain?

title: Taylor to retire after Dublin bout later this year
partialText: Katie Taylor confirms she will bring the curtain down on her decorated career after a farewell fight in Dublin this summer.

title: Chelsea and West Ham fined over 'mass confrontation'
partialText: Chelsea and West Ham are fined £325,000 and £300,000 respectively for a "mass confrontation" between players in their match in January.
